title: Geodesics in planar Poisson roads random metric
authors: Guillaume Blanc, Nicolas Curien, Jonas Kahn
abstract:
We study the structure of geodesics in the fractal random metric constructed
by Kendall from a self-similar Poisson process of roads (i.e, lines with speed
limits) in $\mathbb{R}^2$. In particular, we prove a conjecture of Kendall
stating that geodesics do not pause en route, i.e, use roads of arbitrary small
speed except at their endpoints. It follows that the geodesic frame of
$\left(\mathbb{R}^2,T\right)$ is the set of points on roads. We also consider
geodesic stars and hubs, and give a complete description of the local structure
of geodesics around points on roads. Notably, we prove that leaving a road by
driving off-road is never geodesic.
